Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Transmitting Diagnostic Skills in Tibetan Medicine: Embodied Practices for Indigenous Categories of Cancer

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Emory University doctoral candidate Tawni L. Tidwell, supervised by Dr. Carol M. Worthman, will investigate biocultural understandings of how humans create and teach complex knowledge systems. The focus of the research will be on how medical knowledge and epistemologies are conceptualized, transmitted, and then enacted in practical skill. Using Tibetan medicine as a case study, she will examine how diagnosis is formally transmitted, cultivated, and clinically deployed, in this 2,000 year-old text-based, orally-instructed, and practically-implemented non-Western system. What are the learning processes and related sociocultural structure that support such a system in its enactment of diagnostic skill? What do these processes tell us about the transmission of complex knowledge systems more generally?

As the first western student in Men-Tsee-Khang, the premier Tibetan medical school, Tidwell will undertake her investigation with Tibetan medical student peers, faculty, and a group of expert physicians. She will document how diagnostic skills are transmitted, cultivated and applied, with particular regard to a Tibetan medical illness category called dres-nad. The focus on dres-nad is strategic because dres-nads and biomedical cancers are the illness categories in which the Tibetan medical and western biomedical systems most closely overlap. As such, this overlap opens a space in which to elucidate the distinctive features of the two systems of diagnosis and care. Through class participant-observation, student and faculty interviews, and expert physician clinical observations, Tidwell will look at these processes, influences and methods of how situated knowledge of the body interacts with knowledge practice systems to develop skill development and further such skills toward expertise with specific regard to dres-nad.

This research will provide insight into the transmission of complex systems of knowledge by illuminating medical education in a sophisticated, rigorous and systematic non-Western medical system. The study will facilitate international research collaborations and partnerships. Funding this research also supports the education of a graduate student.

In terms of intellectual merit, this project contributes to two areas in anthropology theory and practice: 

1.  Explication of cultural knowledge transmission processes of a tradition focused on effective transmission of practiced skills, and 
2.  Biocultural understandings of how humans create and teach complex knowledge systems around health and well-being.  

I. Cultural knowledge transmission

With respect to how cultural knowledge is transmitted, particularly, knowledge of practice, or technologies, Tibetan physicians describe their tradition as a textually-based, orally-instructed, practically-implemented knowledge transmission system that extends at least 2,000 years.  The principal investigator was fully immersed in the traditional education system for thirty-six months, completing the full four-year curriculum of Tibetan medicine during this time, and becoming the first Westerner to do so. The first half of the study was conducted at the premier Tibetan medical education institute outside of Tibet – Men-Tsee-Khang – and the second half in eastern Tibet in the capital city, Xining, Qinghai Province of the People’s Republic of China at the Tibetan Medical College of Qinghai University.  The shift to Xining allowed her to observe differences inside and outside Tibet of how Tibetan medical pedagogy, cultural transmission processes, transmission of practiced skills, and bicultural understandings of how a similar ethnic and cultural population create and teach a complex knowledge system around health and well-being.  

Many among the Tibetan community assume that an exile context allows for better cultural preservation.  However, this study evaluated this presumption first-hand, gathering much evidence to the contrary.  The transfer provided significant and unexpected insights into how the respective classroom, clinical and field pedagogies differ inside and outside Tibet, as well as differences in how texts and classroom instructions transfer to practical skill in the clinical context.  The social, economic, and cultural structures that support the system at Men-Tsee-Khang and the system in Xining have provided greater differences in the transmission processes and values than expected.  The former has focused on textual proficiency and the latter on efficacy of practical skill.
